author: Philon Bondenga
title: Low turnout ‘discredits Congolese referendum’ | African News
text:
Congo Republic President Denis Sassou Nguesso votes at a polling station in Brazzaville, Congo, on Sunday. Opposition parties, which boycotted the poll, said on Monday the low turnout would render the result meaningless. Picture: REUTERS/ROCH BAKU Related articles Congo Republic to hold referendum on third presidential term Congo to vote on extending veteran leader’s rule as opposition vows fightback Killings and arrests in Burundi alarm UN rights chief Rwandan court agrees to hear case to block president’s third term Burundi presidential vote not credible, say UN observers BRAZZAVILLE — A referendum held in Congo Republic to decide whether President Denis Sassou Nguesso can legally stand for a third consecutive term should be cancelled due to low turnout, a senior opposition leader said on Monday.
An opposition boycott of Sunday’s referendum means the country’s veteran ruler is likely to have won voters’ support, paving the way for him to run in an election next year and potentially extend his decades-long rule over the oil-producing central African country.
"It (the turnout) totally discredits the referendum. Either they annul it or else he will impose a dictatorship and the Congolese will not accept it," said opposition leader Pascal Tsaty Mabiala, secretary of the Pan-African Union for Social Democracy party.
"The smart thing would be to annul the referendum," he said.
Witnesses said logistical problems had partly hampered the voting in Brazzaville on Sunday but that turnout had picked up later in the day. There was little information about the rest of the country.
They said the counting of votes was proceeding smoothly on Monday.
"We are satisfied to see that the poll was conducted in security. That permitted all residents of Brazzaville to have the chance to go to their polling stations and express their choice without worries," Pierre Cébert Ibocko Onanga, prefect of the city, said.
Mr Sassou Nguesso ruled Congo from 1979 until 1992, when he was defeated in a presidential election. His rule resumed five years later after his forces defeated the then-president in a brief civil war.
Although he won presidential elections in 2002 and 2009, both were marred by accusations of fraud. Term limits as well as his age bar the 71-year-old leader from running again under the current constitution.
Mr Sassou Nguesso is the latest African president to try to prolong his grip on power by changing the constitution. Several other such efforts have provoked violence and four died in Congo last week when security forces opened fire on protesters.
Last October, Burkina Faso’s leader of 27 years was toppled by protests and in July the president of Burundi won a third term amid violent protests. Rwanda and the Democratic Republic of Congo have also sought constitutional change.
Reuters
